      color: 'rgba(255,255,255,0.5)' // Color at 0%
    },
    {
      offset: 1,
      color: '#6690F2' // Color at 100%
    }
  ]
}
  • Conical gradient
// Conical gradient, startAngle represents starting radian, endAngle represents ending radian, x and y are coordinates, and the value range is 0 - 1
{
  gradient: 'conical',
  x: 0.5,
  y: 0.5,
  startAngle: 0,
  endAngle: 6.283185307179586,
  stops: [
    { offset: 0, color: 'red' },      // Color at 0%
    { offset: 0.2, color: 'blue' },   // Color at 20%
    { offset: 0.4, color: 'orange' }, // Color at 40%
    { offset: 0.6, color: 'pink' },   // Color at 60%
    { offset: 0.8, color: 'green' },  // Color at 80%
    { offset: 1, color: 'purple' }    // Color at 100%
  ],
}

When setting images:

Image, supporting multiple formats:

  • string: Image URL
  • HTMLImageElement: The image tag corresponding to the image
  • HTMLCanvasElement: The canvas tag corresponding to the image

path.encode.hover.backgroundMode.desc: The fill mode of the graphic background, depending on the specific graphic

path.encode.hover.cursor.desc:
The mouse cursor style of the graphic, similar to DOM styles:

  • 'auto'
  • 'default'
  • 'none'
  • 'context-menu'
  • 'help'
  • 'pointer'
  • 'progress'
  • 'wait'
  • 'cell'
  • 'crosshair'
  • 'text'
  • 'vertical-text'
  • 'alias'
  • 'copy'
  • 'move'
  • 'no-drop'
  • 'not-allowed'
  • 'grab'
  • 'grabbing'
  • 'all-scroll'
  • 'col-resize'
  • 'row-resize'
  • 'n-resize'
  • 'e-resize'
  • 's-resize'
  • 'w-resize'
  • 'ne-resize'
  • 'nw-resize'
  • 'se-resize'
  • 'sw-resize'
  • 'ew-resize'
  • 'ns-resize'
  • 'nesw-resize'
  • 'nwse-resize'
  • 'zoom-in'
  • 'zoom-out'

path.animation.desc:
Supports setting various state corresponding animations, data-driven animation states have three types:

  • enter
  • update
  • exit

Interaction-triggered state changes are configured through a unified interaction animation, with the configuration key being state

path.animation.type.desc:
Animation execution type, specifying a specific built-in animation execution effect

Universal built-in animation types include:

  • fadeIn/fadeOut: Fade in and out animations
  • scaleIn/scaleOut: Scaling animations
  • moveIn/moveOut: Move in and out animations
  • rotateIn/rotateOut: Rotation animations
  • update: Update animations

path.animation.channel.desc: Visual channels before and after the animation is executed, conflicts with type configuration

path.animation.custom.desc: Custom animation, if custom animation configuration is set, it will replace the default visual channel interpolation logic

path.animation.oneByOne.desc: Animation execution delay time in sequence. If set to true, the next element's animation will be executed after the previous element's animation is completed. The default is false.

path.animation.startTime.desc: Initial time of animation execution, which will not be repeatedly applied in loop animation, default is 0

path.animation.totalTime.desc: Maximum time of animation execution, the animation will be terminated if it reaches the set time

path.animation.loop.desc: Number of animation loops, if set to true, it will loop infinitely

path.animation.options.desc: Additional parameters set for specific animation types execution

path.animation.controlOptions.desc:
Control parameters for animation execution logic:

  • stopWhenStateChange: Whether to immediately terminate its animation when the animation state changes
  • immediatelyApply: Whether to immediately apply the initial visual channel of the animation

path.zIndex.desc: Set the zIndex of the container shape (group) corresponding to the mark graphic primitive

path.context.desc: Set the context parameters of the graphic primitive

path.setCustomizedShape.desc:
Set the callback function of custom shape. The corresponding ts type is as follows:

(datum: any[], attrs: any, path: ICustomPath2D) => ICustomPath2D;

Where ICustomPath2D is a utility class provided by VRender for drawing custom paths.

path.support3d.desc: Whether to support 3d mode when the canvas is set to 3d view.

path.group.desc:
Set the parent graphic primitive. Supports two formats:

  • 'string' The id of the corresponding parent graphic primitive
  • 'IGroupMark' The corresponding grammar element of the parent graphic primitive, generally used in API call scenarios.

If not set, it will be attached to the root node of the canvas by default.

path.from.desc:
ts type definition is:

interface MarkFromSpec {
  data: string | IData;
}

Declare the data on which the graphic primitive depends through the data attribute.

path.key.desc:
Set the unique identifier for the graphic primitive data element, which is used to calculate the data state of the graphic element. The corresponding ts type definition is:

type MarkKeySpec = string | ((datum: any) => string);

That is to say, it supports two formats:

  • string Set the field corresponding to the key
  • function Customize the callback function for parsing the key

path.sort.desc:
Sort all graphic elements in the graphic primitive and set the corresponding sorting callback function:

(datumA: any, datumB: any) => number;

path.groupBy.desc:
Set the grouping attribute, the corresponding ts type definition is:

type MarkKeySpec = string | ((datum: any) => string);

That is to say, it supports two formats:

  • string Set the field corresponding to the grouping key
  • function Customize the callback function for parsing the grouping key

path.groupSort.desc:
Sort the groups in the graphic primitive and set the corresponding sorting callback function:

(datumA: any, datumB: any) => number;

path.coordinate.desc: Set the id or graphic element corresponding to the associated coordinate system of this graphic primitive

path.state.desc:
Set the state values of all graphical elements of the current graphic primitive, supporting three formats:

  • string Set the state of the graphic, for example, { state: 'selected'} sets the state of all graphics to 'selected', usually in this case, the encode also sets the graphic channel mapping corresponding to the 'selected' state
  • string[] Set multiple states for the graphic, you can configure stateSort to influence the order of executing the graphic channel mapping corresponding to the state
  • function Customize the callback function for parsing the state value, and the return parameter is string | string[], the corresponding ts type definition is:
(datum: any, element: IElement, parameters: any) => string | string[];

path.stateSort.desc:
Set the sorting function of the state values of all graphics elements of the current graphic primitive, which will affect the order of the graphic channel mapping corresponding to the state. The result of the graphic channel mapping executed earlier may be covered by subsequent states. The corresponding ts type definition is:

(stateA: string, stateB: string) => number;

path.transform.desc:
Set the corresponding transformation of the graphic primitive. All data transformations can be configured on the graphic primitive and are used for the join data execution transformation; Another type of transformation is the transformation executed by graphical elements, such as dodge; The general type definition is as follows:

interface BaseTransformSpec {
  /** the type of transform */
  type: string;
  [key: string]: TransformSpecValue | TransformSpecValue[];
}

The parameters supported by each transformation are different

path.layout.desc:
Set the layout parameters of the graphic primitive. There are two roles when the graphic primitive participates in the layout:

  • 'container' Container graphic primitive, usually group graphic primitive
  • 'item' layout child element, as a child node of the container graphic primitive

Please note that we only support one layer of layout. If it is a multi-layer nested layout, it is recommended to use a custom layout scheme for implementation;

Now support two content layouts: grid layout and relative layout, the related type definition is as follows

type MarkLayoutCallback = (
  group: IGroupMark,
  children: IMark[],
  parentLayoutBounds: Bounds,
  options?: ILayoutOptions
) => void;

interface MarkBaseLayoutSpec {
  callback?: MarkLayoutCallback;
  skipBeforeLayouted?: boolean;
  updateViewSignals?: boolean;
}

interface MarkGridContainerSpec extends MarkBaseLayoutSpec {
  display: 'grid';
  gridTemplateRows?: (number | string | 'auto')[];
  gridTemplateColumns?: (number | string | 'auto')[];
  gridRowGap?: number;
  gridColumnGap?: number;
}

interface MarkGridItemSpec extends MarkBaseLayoutSpec {
  gridRowStart?: number;
  gridRowEnd?: number;
  gridColumnStart?: number;
  gridColumnEnd?: number;
}

interface MarkRelativeContainerSpec extends MarkBaseLayoutSpec {
  display: 'relative';
  maxChildWidth?: string | number;
  maxChildHeight?: string | number;
}

interface MarkRelativeItemSpec extends MarkBaseLayoutSpec {
  position?: 'top' | 'bottom' | 'left' | 'right' | 'content' | 'auto' | string;
  padding?: CommonPaddingSpec;
}

If you want to set a custom layout scheme, layout also supports setting callback functions directly. The definition of the callback function is as follows:

type MarkLayoutCallback = (
  group: IGroupMark,
  children: IMark[],
  parentLayoutBounds: Bounds,
  options?: ILayoutOptions
) => void;

path.layout.display.desc:
The container graphic primitive sets the layout type and supports two configurations:

  • 'relative' Relative layout
  • 'grid' Grid layout

path.layout.callback.desc:
Customize the callback function for this graphic primitive, the ts type definition is:

type MarkLayoutCallback = (
  group: IGroupMark,
  children: IMark[],
  parentLayoutBounds: Bounds,
  options?: ILayoutOptions
) => void;

path.layout.skipBeforeLayouted.desc: Skip the execution stage before the layout is completed

path.layout.updateViewSignals.desc:
Whether to update the default view signals, that is: padding, viewWidth and viewHeight

This property can only be set on a container graphic primitive with 'relative' layout.

path.layout.maxChildWidth.desc:
The parent graphic primitives of the relative layout set the maximum width of the child graphic primitives, supporting two formats:

  • 'string' Percentage string, such as '20%', the denominator corresponds to the width of the bounding box of the container graphic primitive
  • 'number' Unit is px, set the absolute width

path.layout.maxChildHeight.desc:
The parent graphic primitives of the relative layout set the maximum height of the child graphic primitives, supporting two formats:

  • 'string' Percentage string, such as '20%', the denominator corresponds to the height of the bounding box of the container graphic primitive
  • 'number' Unit is px, set the absolute width

path.layout.position.desc:
Set the position of the child graphic primitive of the relative layout. The supported settings are:

  • 'top' Relative to the top of the parent graphic primitive
  • 'bottom' Relative to the bottom of the parent graphic primitive
  • 'left' Relative to the left side of the parent graphic primitive
  • 'right' Relative to the right side of the parent graphic primitive
  • 'content' Relative to the center of the parent graphic primitive, that is, the content area
  • 'auto' When the graphic primitive sets the coordinate system, the position relative to the parent graphic primitive is automatically calculated according to the associated scale

path.layout.padding.desc:
The inner padding of Child graphic primitive, in px unit, with the default padding of 0 for all directions. Accepts numerical values, numerical arrays, and objects for settings.

Example of usage:

// Numerical type, set the padding to 5
padding: 5;
// Numerical array, set the top and bottom padding to 5, and the left and right padding to 10, similar to the CSS box model
padding: [5, 10];
// Numerical array, set the padding for all four directions separately
padding: [
  5, // Top
  10, // Right
  5, // Bottom
  10 // Left
];
// Object type
padding: {
  top: 5,
  right: 10,
  bottom: 5,
  left: 10
}

path.layout.gridTemplateRows.desc: The parent graphic primitive of the grid layout sets the row height

path.layout.gridTemplateColumns.desc: The parent graphic primitive of the grid layout sets the column width

path.layout.gridRowGap.desc: The parent graphic primitive of the grid layout sets the row spacing

path.layout.gridColumnGap.desc: The parent graphic primitive of the grid layout sets the column spacing

path.layout.gridRowStart.desc: The child graphic primitive of the grid layout sets the row start position

path.layout.gridRowEnd.desc: The child graphic primitive of the grid layout sets the row end position

path.layout.gridColumnStart.desc: The child graphic primitive of the grid layout sets the column start position

path.layout.gridColumnEnd.desc: The child graphic primitive of the grid layout sets the column end position

path.large.desc: Whether to enable large data rendering mode

path.largeThreshold.desc: The threshold for enabling large data rendering optimization, corresponding to the length of data

path.progressiveStep.desc: The step length for enabling progressive rendering, corresponding to the length of data in each shard

path.progressiveThreshold.desc: The threshold for enabling progressive rendering, corresponding to the length of single series data

path.morph.desc: Whether to enable global transition morph animations for the current graphic element

path.morphKey.desc: Used to match graphic elements for global transition morph animations, graphic elements with the same morphKey will undergo morph animations

path.morphElementKey.desc: For the matched graphic elements before and after, use this configuration to match the graphic element; if not declared, we will read the key configuration by default to match the graphic element for morph animations; Supports one-to-one, one-to-many, and many-to-one graphic morph animations by default

area.encode.desc:
Set the visual channel encoding of the graphics elements, supporting three data change states by default:

  • enter newly added data items
  • update data items have been updated
  • exit data items are deleted

Note that the data state here is automatically generated based on the mark's key. We will calculate the unique identifier for the data bound to the mark based on the key configuration. After the data is updated, if the corresponding unique identifier no longer exists, the state is exit; if it exists, it is update. If the previous data does not exist for the unique identifier, the data item's state is enter.

Supports one interaction state by default:

  • hover when the mouse hovers over a specific shape, set the corresponding visual channel encoding for the shape

area.encode.enter.desc: Set the visual channel mapping executed by the graphics elements in the data initialization state. Note that it will not be executed again when the data is updated.

area.encode.enter.enableSegments.desc: Whether to enable segmented style; because parsing segmented style requires a certain amount of performance consumption, this function will only be turned on when the style of all points is detected to be different

area.encode.enter.curveType.desc:
The type of line, supporting the following options

  • 'basis'
  • 'basisClosed'
  • 'basisOpen'
  • 'bundle'
  • 'cardinal'
  • 'cardinalClosed'
  • 'cardinalOpen'
  • 'stepBefore'
  • 'stepAfter'
  • 'catmullRom'
  • 'catmullRomClosed'
  • 'catmullRomOpen'
  • 'linear'
  • 'linearClosed'
  • 'monotoneX'
  • 'monotoneY'
  • 'natural'
  • 'radial'
  • 'step'

area.encode.enter.z.desc: Graphic element's z coordinate, only applicable to 3D graphics

area.encode.enter.fill.desc:
Graphic element's fill color. Supports setting solid color using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, and gradient color fills.

Gradient color configuration. Gradient colors can be configured on color-supporting properties such as fill and stroke in graphic styles. Currently supports three gradient configurations:

  • Linear gradient
// Linear gradient, the first four parameters are x0, y0, x1, y1, ranging from 0 to 1, which is equivalent to the percentage within the bounding box of the graphic
{
  gradient: 'linear',
  x0: 0,
  y0: 0,
  x1: 0,
  y1: 1,
  stops: [
    {
      offset: 0,
      color: 'red' // Color at 0%
    },
    {
      offset: 1,
      color: 'blue' // Color at 100%
    }
  ],
}
  • Radial gradient
// Radial gradient, the first five parameters are x0, y0, r0, x1, y1, r1, where r0 and r1 represent radius, values are the same as linear gradient
{
  gradient: 'radial',
  x0: 0.5,
  y0: 0,
  r0: 0,
  x1: 0.5,
  y1: 1,
  r1: 0.7,
  stops: [
    {
      offset: 0,
      color: 'rgba(255,255,255,0.5)' // Color at 0%
    },
    {
      offset: 1,
      color: '#6690F2' // Color at 100%
    }
  ]
}
  • Conical gradient
// Conical gradient, startAngle represents starting radian, endAngle represents ending radian, x and y are coordinates, and the value range is 0 - 1
{
  gradient: 'conical',
  x: 0.5,
  y: 0.5,
  startAngle: 0,
  endAngle: 6.283185307179586,
  stops: [
    { offset: 0, color: 'red' },      // Color at 0%
    { offset: 0.2, color: 'blue' },   // Color at 20%
    { offset: 0.4, color: 'orange' }, // Color at 40%
    { offset: 0.6, color: 'pink' },   // Color at 60%
    { offset: 0.8, color: 'green' },  // Color at 80%
    { offset: 1, color: 'purple' }    // Color at 100%
  ],
}

area.encode.enter.stroke.desc:
Graphic element's stroke color. Supports setting solid color using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, and gradient color fills.

Gradient color configuration. Gradient colors can be configured on color-supporting properties such as fill and stroke in graphic styles. Currently supports three gradient configurations:

  • Linear gradient

  • Radial gradient

  • Conical gradient

    { offset: 0.6, color: 'pink' },   // Color at 60%
    { offset: 0.8, color: 'green' },  // Color at 80%

area.encode.enter.lineWidth.desc: Line width of the graphic element's stroke

area.encode.enter.lineDash.desc: Type: number[] Line pattern mode of the graphic element's stroke

area.encode.enter.lineDashOffset.desc: Offset of the graphic element's stroke line pattern mode

area.encode.enter.lineCap.desc:
Line cap style of the graphic stroke, with the following optional options:

  • 'butt'
  • 'round'
  • 'square'

area.encode.enter.lineJoin.desc:
Line join style of the graphic stroke, with the following optional options:

  • 'bevel'
  • 'miter'
  • 'round'

area.encode.enter.miterLimit.desc: The limit value for the miter effect when the lineJoin type is miter

area.encode.enter.strokeBoundsBuffer.desc: The boundsBuffer of the graphic stroke for controlling the buffer of the bounds

area.encode.enter.shadowBlur.desc: The blur radius size of the graphic shadow

area.encode.enter.shadowColor.desc:
The shadow color of the graphic. Supports setting to solid colors using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, etc., and also supports setting to gradient color fills.

Gradient color configuration. Gradient colors can be configured on color-supporting properties such as fill and stroke in graphic styles. Currently supports three gradient configurations:

  • Linear gradient
// Linear gradient, the first four parameters are x0, y0, x1, y1, ranging from 0 to 1, which is equivalent to the percentage within the bounding box of the graphic

area.encode.enter.shadowOffsetX.desc: The x offset of the graphic shadow

area.encode.enter.shadowOffsetY.desc: The y offset of the graphic shadow

area.encode.enter.dx.desc: The offset of the graphic in the x direction

area.encode.enter.dy.desc: The offset of the graphic in the y direction

area.encode.enter.dz.desc: The offset of the graphic in the z direction

area.encode.enter.scrollX.desc: The scrolling offset of the graphic in the X direction

area.encode.enter.scrollY.desc: The scrolling offset of the graphic in the y direction

area.encode.enter.scaleX.desc: The scaling factor of the graphic in the x direction, default is no scaling, which is equivalent to a value of 1

area.encode.enter.scaleY.desc: The scaling factor of the graphic in the y direction, default is no scaling, which is equivalent to a value of 1

area.encode.enter.scaleZ.desc: The scaling factor of the graphic in the z direction, default is no scaling, which is equivalent to a value of 1

area.encode.enter.angle.desc: The rotation angle of the graphic in the x-y plane, in 3d mode, corresponds to the rotation angle around the z-axis

area.encode.enter.alpha.desc: The rotation angle around the y-axis in 3d mode

area.encode.enter.beta.desc: The rotation angle around the x-axis in 3d mode

area.encode.enter.background.desc:

When setting the background color, supports using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, etc. to set solid colors, and also supports setting gradient color fills.

area.encode.update.fill.desc:
Graphic element's fill color. Supports setting solid color using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, and gradient color fills.

Gradient color configuration. Gradient colors can be configured on color-supporting properties such as fill and stroke in graphic styles. Currently supports three gradient configurations:

  • Linear gradient
// Linear gradient, the first four parameters are x0, y0, x1, y1, ranging from 0 to 1, which is equivalent to the percentage within the bounding box of the graphic
{
  gradient: 'linear',
  x0: 0,
  y0: 0,
  x1: 0,
  y1: 1,
  stops: [
    {
      offset: 0,
      color: 'red' // Color at 0%
    },
    {
      offset: 1,
      color: 'blue' // Color at 100%
    }
  ],
}
  • Radial gradient
// Radial gradient, the first five parameters are x0, y0, r0, x1, y1, r1, where r0 and r1 represent radius, values are the same as linear gradient
{
  gradient: 'radial',
  x0: 0.5,
  y0: 0,
  r0: 0,
  x1: 0.5,
  y1: 1,
  r1: 0.7,
  stops: [
    {
      offset: 0,
      color: 'rgba(255,255,255,0.5)' // Color at 0%
    },
    {
      offset: 1,
      color: '#6690F2' // Color at 100%
    }
  ]
}
  • Conical gradient
// Conical gradient, startAngle represents starting radian, endAngle represents ending radian, x and y are coordinates, and the value range is 0 - 1
{
  gradient: 'conical',
  x: 0.5,
  y: 0.5,
  startAngle: 0,
  endAngle: 6.283185307179586,
  stops: [
    { offset: 0, color: 'red' },      // Color at 0%
    { offset: 0.2, color: 'blue' },   // Color at 20%
    { offset: 0.4, color: 'orange' }, // Color at 40%
    { offset: 0.6, color: 'pink' },   // Color at 60%
    { offset: 0.8, color: 'green' },  // Color at 80%
    { offset: 1, color: 'purple' }    // Color at 100%
  ],
}

  • 'linearClosed'
  • 'monotoneX'
  • 'monotoneY'
  • 'natural'
  • 'radial'
  • 'step'

area.encode.hover.z.desc: Graphic element's z coordinate, only applicable to 3D graphics

area.encode.hover.fill.desc:
Graphic element's fill color. Supports setting solid color using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, and gradient color fills.

Gradient color configuration. Gradient colors can be configured on color-supporting properties such as fill and stroke in graphic styles. Currently supports three gradient configurations:

  • Linear gradient
// Linear gradient, the first four parameters are x0, y0, x1, y1, ranging from 0 to 1, which is equivalent to the percentage within the bounding box of the graphic
{
  gradient: 'linear',
  x0: 0,
  y0: 0,
  x1: 0,
  y1: 1,
  stops: [
    {
      offset: 0,
      color: 'red' // Color at 0%
    },
    {
      offset: 1,
      color: 'blue' // Color at 100%
    }
  ],
}
  • Radial gradient
// Radial gradient, the first five parameters are x0, y0, r0, x1, y1, r1, where r0 and r1 represent radius, values are the same as linear gradient
{
  gradient: 'radial',
  x0: 0.5,
  y0: 0,
  r0: 0,
  x1: 0.5,
  y1: 1,
  r1: 0.7,
  stops: [
    {
      offset: 0,
      color: 'rgba(255,255,255,0.5)' // Color at 0%
    },
    {
      offset: 1,
      color: '#6690F2' // Color at 100%
    }
  ]
}
  • Conical gradient
// Conical gradient, startAngle represents starting radian, endAngle represents ending radian, x and y are coordinates, and the value range is 0 - 1
{
  gradient: 'conical',
  x: 0.5,
  y: 0.5,
  startAngle: 0,
  endAngle: 6.283185307179586,
  stops: [
    { offset: 0, color: 'red' },      // Color at 0%
    { offset: 0.2, color: 'blue' },   // Color at 20%
    { offset: 0.4, color: 'orange' }, // Color at 40%
    { offset: 0.6, color: 'pink' },   // Color at 60%
    { offset: 0.8, color: 'green' },  // Color at 80%
    { offset: 1, color: 'purple' }    // Color at 100%
  ],
}

area.encode.hover.stroke.desc:

  • Conical gradient

area.encode.hover.lineWidth.desc: Line width of the graphic element's stroke

area.encode.hover.lineDash.desc: Type: number[] Line pattern mode of the graphic element's stroke

area.encode.hover.lineDashOffset.desc: Offset of the graphic element's stroke line pattern mode

area.encode.hover.lineCap.desc:
Line cap style of the graphic stroke, with the following optional options:

  • 'butt'
  • 'round'
  • 'square'

area.encode.hover.lineJoin.desc:
Line join style of the graphic stroke, with the following optional options:

  • 'bevel'
  • 'miter'
  • 'round'

area.encode.hover.miterLimit.desc: The limit value for the miter effect when the lineJoin type is miter

area.encode.hover.strokeBoundsBuffer.desc: The boundsBuffer of the graphic stroke for controlling the buffer of the bounds

area.encode.hover.shadowBlur.desc: The blur radius size of the graphic shadow

area.encode.hover.shadowColor.desc:
The shadow color of the graphic. Supports setting to solid colors using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, etc., and also supports setting to gradient color fills.

area.encode.hover.shadowOffsetX.desc: The x offset of the graphic shadow

area.encode.hover.shadowOffsetY.desc: The y offset of the graphic shadow

area.encode.hover.dx.desc: The offset of the graphic in the x direction

area.encode.hover.dy.desc: The offset of the graphic in the y direction

area.encode.hover.dz.desc: The offset of the graphic in the z direction

area.encode.hover.scrollX.desc: The scrolling offset of the graphic in the X direction

area.encode.hover.scrollY.desc: The scrolling offset of the graphic in the y direction

area.encode.hover.scaleX.desc: The scaling factor of the graphic in the x direction, default is no scaling, which is equivalent to a value of 1

area.encode.hover.scaleY.desc: The scaling factor of the graphic in the y direction, default is no scaling, which is equivalent to a value of 1

area.encode.hover.scaleZ.desc: The scaling factor of the graphic in the z direction, default is no scaling, which is equivalent to a value of 1

area.encode.hover.angle.desc: The rotation angle of the graphic in the x-y plane, in 3d mode, corresponds to the rotation angle around the z-axis

area.encode.hover.alpha.desc: The rotation angle around the y-axis in 3d mode

area.encode.hover.beta.desc: The rotation angle around the x-axis in 3d mode

area.encode.hover.background.desc:
The background color of the graphic, or the background image;

When setting the background color, supports using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, etc. to set solid colors, and also supports setting gradient color fills.

Gradient color configuration. Gradient colors can be configured on color-supporting properties such as fill and stroke in graphic styles. Currently supports three gradient configurations:

  • Linear gradient
// Linear gradient, the first four parameters are x0, y0, x1, y1, ranging from 0 to 1, which is equivalent to the percentage within the bounding box of the graphic
{

    },

    }
  ],
}
  • Radial gradient
// Radial gradient, the first five parameters are x0, y0, r0, x1, y1, r1, where r0 and r1 represent radius, values are the same as linear gradient
{

  x0: 0.5,
  y0: 0,
  r0: 0,
  x1: 0.5,
  y1: 1,
  r1: 0.7,
  stops: [
    {
      offset: 0,
      color: 'rgba(255,255,255,0.5)' // Color at 0%
    },
    {
      offset: 1,
      color: '#6690F2' // Color at 100%
    }
  ]
}
  • Conical gradient
// Conical gradient, startAngle represents starting radian, endAngle represents ending radian, x and y are coordinates, and the value range is 0 - 1
{
  gradient: 'conical',
  x: 0.5,

  startAngle: 0,
  endAngle: 6.283185307179586,
  stops: [
    { offset: 0, color: 'red' },      // Color at 0%
    { offset: 0.2, color: 'blue' },   // Color at 20%
    { offset: 0.4, color: 'orange' }, // Color at 40%
    { offset: 0.6, color: 'pink' },   // Color at 60%
    { offset: 0.8, color: 'green' },  // Color at 80%
    { offset: 1, color: 'purple' }    // Color at 100%
  ],
}

When setting images:

Image, supporting multiple formats:

  • string: Image URL
  • HTMLImageElement: The image tag corresponding to the image
  • HTMLCanvasElement: The canvas tag corresponding to the image

area.encode.hover.backgroundMode.desc: The fill mode of the graphic background, depending on the specific graphic

area.encode.hover.cursor.desc:
The mouse cursor style of the graphic, similar to DOM styles:

  • 'auto'

  • 'grab'

  • 'row-resize'

  • 'w-resize'
  • 'ne-resize'
  • 'nw-resize'
  • 'se-resize'
  • 'sw-resize'
  • 'ew-resize'
  • 'ns-resize'
  • 'nesw-resize'
  • 'nwse-resize'
  • 'zoom-in'
  • 'zoom-out'

area.animation.desc:
Supports setting various state corresponding animations, data-driven animation states have three types:

  • enter
  • update
  • exit

Interaction-triggered state changes are configured through a unified interaction animation, with the configuration key being state

area.animation.type.desc:
Animation execution type, specifying a specific built-in animation execution effect

Universal built-in animation types include:

  • fadeIn/fadeOut: Fade in and out animations
  • scaleIn/scaleOut: Scaling animations
  • moveIn/moveOut: Move in and out animations
  • rotateIn/rotateOut: Rotation animations
  • update: Update animations

area primitive additional supported animation types include:

  • growPointsIn/growPointsOut: Point growing animation
  • growPointsXIn/growPointsXOut: X direction point growing animation
  • growPointsYIn/growPointsYOut: Y direction point growing animation
  • clipIn/clipOut: Clipping animation

area.animation.channel.desc: Visual channels before and after the animation is executed, conflicts with type configuration

area.animation.custom.desc: Custom animation, if custom animation configuration is set, it will replace the default visual channel interpolation logic

area.animation.oneByOne.desc: Animation execution delay time in sequence. If set to true, the next element's animation will be executed after the previous element's animation is completed. The default is false.

area.animation.startTime.desc: Initial time of animation execution, which will not be repeatedly applied in loop animation, default is 0

area.animation.totalTime.desc: Maximum time of animation execution, the animation will be terminated if it reaches the set time

area.animation.loop.desc: Number of animation loops, if set to true, it will loop infinitely

area.animation.options.desc: Additional parameters set for specific animation types execution

area.animation.controlOptions.desc:
Control parameters for animation execution logic:

  • stopWhenStateChange: Whether to immediately terminate its animation when the animation state changes
  • immediatelyApply: Whether to immediately apply the initial visual channel of the animation

area.zIndex.desc: Set the zIndex of the container shape (group) corresponding to the mark graphic primitive

area.context.desc: Set the context parameters of the graphic primitive

area.setCustomizedShape.desc:
Set the callback function of custom shape. The corresponding ts type is as follows:

(datum: any[], attrs: any, path: ICustomPath2D) => ICustomPath2D;

Where ICustomPath2D is a utility class provided by VRender for drawing custom paths.

area.support3d.desc: Whether to support 3d mode when the canvas is set to 3d view.

area.group.desc:
Set the parent graphic primitive. Supports two formats:

  • 'string' The id of the corresponding parent graphic primitive
  • 'IGroupMark' The corresponding grammar element of the parent graphic primitive, generally used in API call scenarios.

If not set, it will be attached to the root node of the canvas by default.

area.from.desc:
ts type definition is:

interface MarkFromSpec {
  data: string | IData;
}

Declare the data on which the graphic primitive depends through the data attribute.

area.key.desc:
Set the unique identifier for the graphic primitive data element, which is used to calculate the data state of the graphic element. The corresponding ts type definition is:

type MarkKeySpec = string | ((datum: any) => string);

That is to say, it supports two formats:

  • string Set the field corresponding to the key
  • function Customize the callback function for parsing the key

area.sort.desc:
Sort all graphic elements in the graphic primitive and set the corresponding sorting callback function:

(datumA: any, datumB: any) => number;

area.groupBy.desc:
Set the grouping attribute, the corresponding ts type definition is:

type MarkKeySpec = string | ((datum: any) => string);

That is to say, it supports two formats:

  • string Set the field corresponding to the grouping key
  • function Customize the callback function for parsing the grouping key

area.groupSort.desc:
Sort the groups in the graphic primitive and set the corresponding sorting callback function:

(datumA: any, datumB: any) => number;

area.coordinate.desc: Set the id or graphic element corresponding to the associated coordinate system of this graphic primitive

area.state.desc:
Set the state values of all graphical elements of the current graphic primitive, supporting three formats:

  • string Set the state of the graphic, for example, { state: 'selected'} sets the state of all graphics to 'selected', usually in this case, the encode also sets the graphic channel mapping corresponding to the 'selected' state
  • string[] Set multiple states for the graphic, you can configure stateSort to influence the order of executing the graphic channel mapping corresponding to the state
  • function Customize the callback function for parsing the state value, and the return parameter is string | string[], the corresponding ts type definition is:
(datum: any, element: IElement, parameters: any) => string | string[];

area.stateSort.desc:
Set the sorting function of the state values of all graphics elements of the current graphic primitive, which will affect the order of the graphic channel mapping corresponding to the state. The result of the graphic channel mapping executed earlier may be covered by subsequent states. The corresponding ts type definition is:

(stateA: string, stateB: string) => number;

area.transform.desc:
Set the corresponding transformation of the graphic primitive. All data transformations can be configured on the graphic primitive and are used for the join data execution transformation; Another type of transformation is the transformation executed by graphical elements, such as dodge; The general type definition is as follows:

interface BaseTransformSpec {
  /** the type of transform */
  type: string;
  [key: string]: TransformSpecValue | TransformSpecValue[];
}

The parameters supported by each transformation are different

area.layout.desc:
Set the layout parameters of the graphic primitive. There are two roles when the graphic primitive participates in the layout:

  • 'container' Container graphic primitive, usually group graphic primitive
  • 'item' layout child element, as a child node of the container graphic primitive

Please note that we only support one layer of layout. If it is a multi-layer nested layout, it is recommended to use a custom layout scheme for implementation;

Now support two content layouts: grid layout and relative layout, the related type definition is as follows

type MarkLayoutCallback = (
  group: IGroupMark,
  children: IMark[],
  parentLayoutBounds: Bounds,
  options?: ILayoutOptions
) => void;

interface MarkBaseLayoutSpec {
  callback?: MarkLayoutCallback;
  skipBeforeLayouted?: boolean;
  updateViewSignals?: boolean;
}

interface MarkGridContainerSpec extends MarkBaseLayoutSpec {
  display: 'grid';
  gridTemplateRows?: (number | string | 'auto')[];
  gridTemplateColumns?: (number | string | 'auto')[];
  gridRowGap?: number;
  gridColumnGap?: number;
}

interface MarkGridItemSpec extends MarkBaseLayoutSpec {
  gridRowStart?: number;
  gridRowEnd?: number;
  gridColumnStart?: number;
  gridColumnEnd?: number;
}

interface MarkRelativeContainerSpec extends MarkBaseLayoutSpec {
  display: 'relative';
  maxChildWidth?: string | number;
  maxChildHeight?: string | number;
}

interface MarkRelativeItemSpec extends MarkBaseLayoutSpec {
  position?: 'top' | 'bottom' | 'left' | 'right' | 'content' | 'auto' | string;
  padding?: CommonPaddingSpec;
}

If you want to set a custom layout scheme, layout also supports setting callback functions directly. The definition of the callback function is as follows:

type MarkLayoutCallback = (
  group: IGroupMark,
  children: IMark[],
  parentLayoutBounds: Bounds,
  options?: ILayoutOptions
) => void;

area.layout.display.desc:
The container graphic primitive sets the layout type and supports two configurations:

  • 'relative' Relative layout
  • 'grid' Grid layout

area.layout.callback.desc:
Customize the callback function for this graphic primitive, the ts type definition is:

type MarkLayoutCallback = (
  group: IGroupMark,
  children: IMark[],
  parentLayoutBounds: Bounds,
  options?: ILayoutOptions
) => void;

area.layout.skipBeforeLayouted.desc: Skip the execution stage before the layout is completed

area.layout.updateViewSignals.desc:
Whether to update the default view signals, that is: padding, viewWidth and viewHeight

This property can only be set on a container graphic primitive with 'relative' layout.

area.layout.maxChildWidth.desc:
The parent graphic primitives of the relative layout set the maximum width of the child graphic primitives, supporting two formats:

  • 'string' Percentage string, such as '20%', the denominator corresponds to the width of the bounding box of the container graphic primitive
  • 'number' Unit is px, set the absolute width

area.layout.maxChildHeight.desc:
The parent graphic primitives of the relative layout set the maximum height of the child graphic primitives, supporting two formats:

  • 'string' Percentage string, such as '20%', the denominator corresponds to the height of the bounding box of the container graphic primitive
  • 'number' Unit is px, set the absolute width

area.layout.position.desc:
Set the position of the child graphic primitive of the relative layout. The supported settings are:

  • 'top' Relative to the top of the parent graphic primitive
  • 'bottom' Relative to the bottom of the parent graphic primitive
  • 'left' Relative to the left side of the parent graphic primitive
  • 'right' Relative to the right side of the parent graphic primitive
  • 'content' Relative to the center of the parent graphic primitive, that is, the content area
  • 'auto' When the graphic primitive sets the coordinate system, the position relative to the parent graphic primitive is automatically calculated according to the associated scale

area.layout.padding.desc:
The inner padding of Child graphic primitive, in px unit, with the default padding of 0 for all directions. Accepts numerical values, numerical arrays, and objects for settings.

Example of usage:

// Numerical type, set the padding to 5
padding: 5;
// Numerical array, set the top and bottom padding to 5, and the left and right padding to 10, similar to the CSS box model
padding: [5, 10];
// Numerical array, set the padding for all four directions separately
padding: [
  5, // Top
  10, // Right
  5, // Bottom
  10 // Left
];
// Object type
padding: {
  top: 5,
  right: 10,
  bottom: 5,
  left: 10
}

area.layout.gridTemplateRows.desc: The parent graphic primitive of the grid layout sets the row height

area.layout.gridTemplateColumns.desc: The parent graphic primitive of the grid layout sets the column width

area.layout.gridRowGap.desc: The parent graphic primitive of the grid layout sets the row spacing

area.layout.gridColumnGap.desc: The parent graphic primitive of the grid layout sets the column spacing

area.layout.gridRowStart.desc: The child graphic primitive of the grid layout sets the row start position

area.layout.gridRowEnd.desc: The child graphic primitive of the grid layout sets the row end position

area.layout.gridColumnStart.desc: The child graphic primitive of the grid layout sets the column start position

area.layout.gridColumnEnd.desc: The child graphic primitive of the grid layout sets the column end position

area.large.desc: Whether to enable large data rendering mode

area.largeThreshold.desc: The threshold for enabling large data rendering optimization, corresponding to the length of data

area.progressiveStep.desc: The step length for enabling progressive rendering, corresponding to the length of data in each shard

area.progressiveThreshold.desc: The threshold for enabling progressive rendering, corresponding to the length of single series data

area.morph.desc: Whether to enable global transition morph animations for the current graphic element

area.morphKey.desc: Used to match graphic elements for global transition morph animations, graphic elements with the same morphKey will undergo morph animations

area.morphElementKey.desc:
For the matched graphic elements before and after, use this configuration to match the graphic element; if not declared, we will read the key configuration by default to match the graphic element for morph animations; Supports one-to-one, one-to-many, and many-to-one graphic morph animations by default

Line graphic element

line.desc: Line graphic element Test it out

line.encode.desc:
Set the visual channel encoding of the graphics elements, supporting three data change states by default:

  • enter newly added data items
  • update data items have been updated
  • exit data items are deleted

Note that the data state here is automatically generated based on the mark's key. We will calculate the unique identifier for the data bound to the mark based on the key configuration. After the data is updated, if the corresponding unique identifier no longer exists, the state is exit; if it exists, it is update. If the previous data does not exist for the unique identifier, the data item's state is enter.

Supports one interaction state by default:

  • hover when the mouse hovers over a specific shape, set the corresponding visual channel encoding for the shape

line.encode.enter.desc: Set the visual channel mapping executed by the graphics elements in the data initialization state. Note that it will not be executed again when the data is updated.

line.encode.enter.enableSegments.desc: Whether to enable segmented style; because parsing segmented style requires a certain amount of performance consumption, this function will only be turned on when the style of all points is detected to be different

line.encode.enter.curveType.desc:
The type of line, supporting the following options

  • 'basis'
  • 'basisClosed'
  • 'basisOpen'
  • 'bundle'
  • 'cardinal'
  • 'cardinalClosed'
  • 'cardinalOpen'
  • 'stepBefore'
  • 'stepAfter'
  • 'catmullRom'
  • 'catmullRomClosed'
  • 'catmullRomOpen'
  • 'linear'
  • 'linearClosed'
  • 'monotoneX'
  • 'monotoneY'
  • 'natural'
  • 'radial'
  • 'step'

line.encode.enter.z.desc: Graphic element's z coordinate, only applicable to 3D graphics

line.encode.enter.fill.desc:
Graphic element's fill color. Supports setting solid color using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, and gradient color fills.

Gradient color configuration. Gradient colors can be configured on color-supporting properties such as fill and stroke in graphic styles. Currently supports three gradient configurations:

  • Linear gradient
// Linear gradient, the first four parameters are x0, y0, x1, y1, ranging from 0 to 1, which is equivalent to the percentage within the bounding box of the graphic
{
  gradient: 'linear',
  x0: 0,
  y0: 0,
  x1: 0,
  y1: 1,
  stops: [
    {
      offset: 0,
      color: 'red' // Color at 0%
    },
    {
      offset: 1,
      color: 'blue' // Color at 100%
    }
  ],
}
  • Radial gradient
// Radial gradient, the first five parameters are x0, y0, r0, x1, y1, r1, where r0 and r1 represent radius, values are the same as linear gradient
{
  gradient: 'radial',
  x0: 0.5,
  y0: 0,
  r0: 0,
  x1: 0.5,
  y1: 1,
  r1: 0.7,
  stops: [
    {
      offset: 0,
      color: 'rgba(255,255,255,0.5)' // Color at 0%
    },
    {
      offset: 1,
      color: '#6690F2' // Color at 100%
    }
  ]
}
  • Conical gradient
// Conical gradient, startAngle represents starting radian, endAngle represents ending radian, x and y are coordinates, and the value range is 0 - 1
{
  gradient: 'conical',
  x: 0.5,
  y: 0.5,
  startAngle: 0,
  endAngle: 6.283185307179586,
  stops: [
    { offset: 0, color: 'red' },      // Color at 0%
    { offset: 0.2, color: 'blue' },   // Color at 20%
    { offset: 0.4, color: 'orange' }, // Color at 40%
    { offset: 0.6, color: 'pink' },   // Color at 60%
    { offset: 0.8, color: 'green' },  // Color at 80%
    { offset: 1, color: 'purple' }    // Color at 100%
  ],

line.encode.enter.stroke.desc:
Graphic element's stroke color. Supports setting solid color using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, and gradient color fills.

Gradient color configuration. Gradient colors can be configured on color-supporting properties such as fill and stroke in graphic styles. Currently supports three gradient configurations:

  • Linear gradient
// Linear gradient, the first four parameters are x0, y0, x1, y1, ranging from 0 to 1, which is equivalent to the percentage within the bounding box of the graphic
{
  gradient: 'linear',
  x0: 0,
  y0: 0,
  x1: 0,
  y1: 1,
  stops: [
    {
      offset: 0,
      color: 'red' // Color at 0%
    },
    {
      offset: 1,
      color: 'blue' // Color at 100%
    }
  ],
}
  • Radial gradient
// Radial gradient, the first five parameters are x0, y0, r0, x1, y1, r1, where r0 and r1 represent radius, values are the same as linear gradient
{
  gradient: 'radial',
  x0: 0.5,
  y0: 0,
  r0: 0,
  x1: 0.5,
  y1: 1,
  r1: 0.7,
  stops: [
    {
      offset: 0,
      color: 'rgba(255,255,255,0.5)' // Color at 0%
    },
    {
      offset: 1,
      color: '#6690F2' // Color at 100%
    }
  ]
}
  • Conical gradient
// Conical gradient, startAngle represents starting radian, endAngle represents ending radian, x and y are coordinates, and the value range is 0 - 1
{
  gradient: 'conical',
  x: 0.5,
  y: 0.5,
  startAngle: 0,
  endAngle: 6.283185307179586,
  stops: [
    { offset: 0, color: 'red' },      // Color at 0%
    { offset: 0.2, color: 'blue' },   // Color at 20%
    { offset: 0.4, color: 'orange' }, // Color at 40%
    { offset: 0.6, color: 'pink' },   // Color at 60%
    { offset: 0.8, color: 'green' },  // Color at 80%
    { offset: 1, color: 'purple' }    // Color at 100%
  ],
}

Graphic element's stroke color. Supports setting solid color using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, and gradient color fills.

Gradient color configuration. Gradient colors can be configured on color-supporting properties such as fill and stroke in graphic styles. Currently supports three gradient configurations:

  • Linear gradient
// Linear gradient, the first four parameters are x0, y0, x1, y1, ranging from 0 to 1, which is equivalent to the percentage within the bounding box of the graphic
{
  gradient: 'linear',
  x0: 0,
  y0: 0,
  x1: 0,
  y1: 1,
  stops: [
    {
      offset: 0,
      color: 'red' // Color at 0%
    },
    {
      offset: 1,
      color: 'blue' // Color at 100%
    }
  ],
}
  • Radial gradient
// Radial gradient, the first five parameters are x0, y0, r0, x1, y1, r1, where r0 and r1 represent radius, values are the same as linear gradient
{
  gradient: 'radial',
  x0: 0.5,
  y0: 0,
  r0: 0,
  x1: 0.5,
  y1: 1,
  r1: 0.7,
  stops: [
    {
      offset: 0,
      color: 'rgba(255,255,255,0.5)' // Color at 0%
    },
    {
      offset: 1,
      color: '#6690F2' // Color at 100%
    }
  ]
}
  • Conical gradient
// Conical gradient, startAngle represents starting radian, endAngle represents ending radian, x and y are coordinates, and the value range is 0 - 1
{
  gradient: 'conical',
  x: 0.5,
  y: 0.5,
  startAngle: 0,
  endAngle: 6.283185307179586,
  stops: [
    { offset: 0, color: 'red' },      // Color at 0%
    { offset: 0.2, color: 'blue' },   // Color at 20%
    { offset: 0.4, color: 'orange' }, // Color at 40%
    { offset: 0.6, color: 'pink' },   // Color at 60%
    { offset: 0.8, color: 'green' },  // Color at 80%
    { offset: 1, color: 'purple' }    // Color at 100%
  ],
}

line.animation.desc:
Supports setting various state corresponding animations, data-driven animation states have three types:

  • enter
  • update
  • exit

Interaction-triggered state changes are configured through a unified interaction animation, with the configuration key being state

line.animation.type.desc:
Animation execution type, specifying a specific built-in animation execution effect

Universal built-in animation types include:

  • fadeIn/fadeOut: Fade in and out animations
  • scaleIn/scaleOut: Scaling animations
  • moveIn/moveOut: Move in and out animations
  • rotateIn/rotateOut: Rotation animations
  • update: Update animations

line primitive additional supported animation types include:

  • growPointsIn/growPointsOut: Point growing animation
  • growPointsXIn/growPointsXOut: X direction point growing animation
  • growPointsYIn/growPointsYOut: Y direction point growing animation
  • clipIn/clipOut: Clipping animation

line.animation.channel.desc: Visual channels before and after the animation is executed, conflicts with type configuration

line.animation.custom.desc: Custom animation, if custom animation configuration is set, it will replace the default visual channel interpolation logic

line.animation.oneByOne.desc: Animation execution delay time in sequence. If set to true, the next element's animation will be executed after the previous element's animation is completed. The default is false.

line.animation.startTime.desc: Initial time of animation execution, which will not be repeatedly applied in loop animation, default is 0

line.animation.totalTime.desc: Maximum time of animation execution, the animation will be terminated if it reaches the set time

line.animation.loop.desc: Number of animation loops, if set to true, it will loop infinitely

line.animation.options.desc: Additional parameters set for specific animation types execution

line.animation.controlOptions.desc:
Control parameters for animation execution logic:

  • stopWhenStateChange: Whether to immediately terminate its animation when the animation state changes
  • immediatelyApply: Whether to immediately apply the initial visual channel of the animation

line.zIndex.desc: Set the zIndex of the container shape (group) corresponding to the mark graphic primitive

line.context.desc: Set the context parameters of the graphic primitive

line.setCustomizedShape.desc:
Set the callback function of custom shape. The corresponding ts type is as follows:

(datum: any[], attrs: any, path: ICustomPath2D) => ICustomPath2D;

Where ICustomPath2D is a utility class provided by VRender for drawing custom paths.

line.support3d.desc: Whether to support 3d mode when the canvas is set to 3d view.

line.group.desc:
Set the parent graphic primitive. Supports two formats:

  • 'string' The id of the corresponding parent graphic primitive
  • 'IGroupMark' The corresponding grammar element of the parent graphic primitive, generally used in API call scenarios.

If not set, it will be attached to the root node of the canvas by default.

line.from.desc:
ts type definition is:

interface MarkFromSpec {
  data: string | IData;
}

Declare the data on which the graphic primitive depends through the data attribute.

line.key.desc:
Set the unique identifier for the graphic primitive data element, which is used to calculate the data state of the graphic element. The corresponding ts type definition is:

type MarkKeySpec = string | ((datum: any) => string);

That is to say, it supports two formats:

  • string Set the field corresponding to the key
  • function Customize the callback function for parsing the key

line.sort.desc:
Sort all graphic elements in the graphic primitive and set the corresponding sorting callback function:

(datumA: any, datumB: any) => number;

line.groupBy.desc:
Set the grouping attribute, the corresponding ts type definition is:

type MarkKeySpec = string | ((datum: any) => string);

That is to say, it supports two formats:

  • string Set the field corresponding to the grouping key
  • function Customize the callback function for parsing the grouping key

line.groupSort.desc:
Sort the groups in the graphic primitive and set the corresponding sorting callback function:

(datumA: any, datumB: any) => number;

line.coordinate.desc: Set the id or graphic element corresponding to the associated coordinate system of this graphic primitive

line.state.desc:
Set the state values of all graphical elements of the current graphic primitive, supporting three formats:

  • string Set the state of the graphic, for example, { state: 'selected'} sets the state of all graphics to 'selected', usually in this case, the encode also sets the graphic channel mapping corresponding to the 'selected' state
  • string[] Set multiple states for the graphic, you can configure stateSort to influence the order of executing the graphic channel mapping corresponding to the state
  • function Customize the callback function for parsing the state value, and the return parameter is string | string[], the corresponding ts type definition is:
(datum: any, element: IElement, parameters: any) => string | string[];

line.stateSort.desc:
Set the sorting function of the state values of all graphics elements of the current graphic primitive, which will affect the order of the graphic channel mapping corresponding to the state. The result of the graphic channel mapping executed earlier may be covered by subsequent states. The corresponding ts type definition is:

(stateA: string, stateB: string) => number;

line.transform.desc:
Set the corresponding transformation of the graphic primitive. All data transformations can be configured on the graphic primitive and are used for the join data execution transformation; Another type of transformation is the transformation executed by graphical elements, such as dodge; The general type definition is as follows:

interface BaseTransformSpec {
  /** the type of transform */
  type: string;
  [key: string]: TransformSpecValue | TransformSpecValue[];
}

The parameters supported by each transformation are different

line.layout.desc:
Set the layout parameters of the graphic primitive. There are two roles when the graphic primitive participates in the layout:

  • 'container' Container graphic primitive, usually group graphic primitive
  • 'item' layout child element, as a child node of the container graphic primitive

Please note that we only support one layer of layout. If it is a multi-layer nested layout, it is recommended to use a custom layout scheme for implementation;

Now support two content layouts: grid layout and relative layout, the related type definition is as follows

type MarkLayoutCallback = (
  group: IGroupMark,
  children: IMark[],
  parentLayoutBounds: Bounds,
  options?: ILayoutOptions
) => void;

interface MarkBaseLayoutSpec {
  callback?: MarkLayoutCallback;
  skipBeforeLayouted?: boolean;
  updateViewSignals?: boolean;
}

interface MarkGridContainerSpec extends MarkBaseLayoutSpec {
  display: 'grid';
  gridTemplateRows?: (number | string | 'auto')[];
  gridTemplateColumns?: (number | string | 'auto')[];
  gridRowGap?: number;
  gridColumnGap?: number;
}

interface MarkGridItemSpec extends MarkBaseLayoutSpec {
  gridRowStart?: number;
  gridRowEnd?: number;
  gridColumnStart?: number;
  gridColumnEnd?: number;
}

interface MarkRelativeContainerSpec extends MarkBaseLayoutSpec {
  display: 'relative';
  maxChildWidth?: string | number;
  maxChildHeight?: string | number;
}

interface MarkRelativeItemSpec extends MarkBaseLayoutSpec {
  position?: 'top' | 'bottom' | 'left' | 'right' | 'content' | 'auto' | string;
  padding?: CommonPaddingSpec;
}

If you want to set a custom layout scheme, layout also supports setting callback functions directly. The definition of the callback function is as follows:

type MarkLayoutCallback = (
  group: IGroupMark,
  children: IMark[],
  parentLayoutBounds: Bounds,
  options?: ILayoutOptions
) => void;

line.layout.display.desc:
The container graphic primitive sets the layout type and supports two configurations:

  • 'relative' Relative layout
  • 'grid' Grid layout

line.layout.callback.desc:
Customize the callback function for this graphic primitive, the ts type definition is:

type MarkLayoutCallback = (
  group: IGroupMark,
  children: IMark[],
  parentLayoutBounds: Bounds,
  options?: ILayoutOptions
) => void;

line.layout.skipBeforeLayouted.desc: Skip the execution stage before the layout is completed

line.layout.updateViewSignals.desc:
Whether to update the default view signals, that is: padding, viewWidth and viewHeight

This property can only be set on a container graphic primitive with 'relative' layout.

line.layout.maxChildWidth.desc:
The parent graphic primitives of the relative layout set the maximum width of the child graphic primitives, supporting two formats:

  • 'string' Percentage string, such as '20%', the denominator corresponds to the width of the bounding box of the container graphic primitive
  • 'number' Unit is px, set the absolute width

line.layout.maxChildHeight.desc:
The parent graphic primitives of the relative layout set the maximum height of the child graphic primitives, supporting two formats:

  • 'string' Percentage string, such as '20%', the denominator corresponds to the height of the bounding box of the container graphic primitive
  • 'number' Unit is px, set the absolute width

line.layout.position.desc:
Set the position of the child graphic primitive of the relative layout. The supported settings are:

  • 'top' Relative to the top of the parent graphic primitive
  • 'bottom' Relative to the bottom of the parent graphic primitive
  • 'left' Relative to the left side of the parent graphic primitive
  • 'right' Relative to the right side of the parent graphic primitive
  • 'content' Relative to the center of the parent graphic primitive, that is, the content area
  • 'auto' When the graphic primitive sets the coordinate system, the position relative to the parent graphic primitive is automatically calculated according to the associated scale

line.layout.padding.desc:
The inner padding of Child graphic primitive, in px unit, with the default padding of 0 for all directions. Accepts numerical values, numerical arrays, and objects for settings.

Example of usage:

// Numerical type, set the padding to 5
padding: 5;
// Numerical array, set the top and bottom padding to 5, and the left and right padding to 10, similar to the CSS box model
padding: [5, 10];
// Numerical array, set the padding for all four directions separately
padding: [
  5, // Top
  10, // Right
  5, // Bottom
  10 // Left
];
// Object type
padding: {
  top: 5,
  right: 10,
  bottom: 5,
  left: 10
}

line.layout.gridTemplateRows.desc: The parent graphic primitive of the grid layout sets the row height

line.layout.gridTemplateColumns.desc: The parent graphic primitive of the grid layout sets the column width

line.layout.gridRowGap.desc: The parent graphic primitive of the grid layout sets the row spacing

line.layout.gridColumnGap.desc: The parent graphic primitive of the grid layout sets the column spacing

line.layout.gridRowStart.desc: The child graphic primitive of the grid layout sets the row start position

line.layout.gridRowEnd.desc: The child graphic primitive of the grid layout sets the row end position

line.layout.gridColumnStart.desc: The child graphic primitive of the grid layout sets the column start position

line.layout.gridColumnEnd.desc: The child graphic primitive of the grid layout sets the column end position

line.large.desc: Whether to enable large data rendering mode

line.largeThreshold.desc: The threshold for enabling large data rendering optimization, corresponding to the length of data

line.progressiveStep.desc: The step length for enabling progressive rendering, corresponding to the length of data in each shard

line.progressiveThreshold.desc: The threshold for enabling progressive rendering, corresponding to the length of single series data

line.morph.desc: Whether to enable global transition morph animations for the current graphic element

line.morphKey.desc: Used to match graphic elements for global transition morph animations, graphic elements with the same morphKey will undergo morph animations

line.morphElementKey.desc: For the matched graphic elements before and after, use this configuration to match the graphic element; if not declared, we will read the key configuration by default to match the graphic element for morph animations; Supports one-to-one, one-to-many, and many-to-one graphic morph animations by default

rule.encode.desc:
Set the visual channel encoding of the graphics elements, supporting three data change states by default:

  • enter newly added data items
  • update data items have been updated
  • exit data items are deleted

Note that the data state here is automatically generated based on the mark's key. We will calculate the unique identifier for the data bound to the mark based on the key configuration. After the data is updated, if the corresponding unique identifier no longer exists, the state is exit; if it exists, it is update. If the previous data does not exist for the unique identifier, the data item's state is enter.

Supports one interaction state by default:

  • hover when the mouse hovers over a specific shape, set the corresponding visual channel encoding for the shape

rule.encode.enter.desc: Set the visual channel mapping executed by the graphics elements in the data initialization state. Note that it will not be executed again when the data is updated.

rule.encode.enter.z.desc: Graphic element's z coordinate, only applicable to 3D graphics

rule.encode.enter.fill.desc:
Graphic element's fill color. Supports setting solid color using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, and gradient color fills.

Gradient color configuration. Gradient colors can be configured on color-supporting properties such as fill and stroke in graphic styles. Currently supports three gradient configurations:

  • Linear gradient
// Linear gradient, the first four parameters are x0, y0, x1, y1, ranging from 0 to 1, which is equivalent to the percentage within the bounding box of the graphic
{
  gradient: 'linear',
  x0: 0,
  y0: 0,
  x1: 0,
  y1: 1,
  stops: [
    {
      offset: 0,
      color: 'red' // Color at 0%
    },
    {
      offset: 1,
      color: 'blue' // Color at 100%
    }
  ],
}
  • Radial gradient
// Radial gradient, the first five parameters are x0, y0, r0, x1, y1, r1, where r0 and r1 represent radius, values are the same as linear gradient
{
  gradient: 'radial',
  x0: 0.5,
  y0: 0,
  r0: 0,
  x1: 0.5,
  y1: 1,
  r1: 0.7,
  stops: [
    {
      offset: 0,
      color: 'rgba(255,255,255,0.5)' // Color at 0%
    },
    {
      offset: 1,
      color: '#6690F2' // Color at 100%
    }
  ]
}
  • Conical gradient
// Conical gradient, startAngle represents starting radian, endAngle represents ending radian, x and y are coordinates, and the value range is 0 - 1
{
  gradient: 'conical',
  x: 0.5,
  y: 0.5,
  startAngle: 0,
  endAngle: 6.283185307179586,
  stops: [
    { offset: 0, color: 'red' },      // Color at 0%
    { offset: 0.2, color: 'blue' },   // Color at 20%
    { offset: 0.4, color: 'orange' }, // Color at 40%
    { offset: 0.6, color: 'pink' },   // Color at 60%
    { offset: 0.8, color: 'green' },  // Color at 80%
    { offset: 1, color: 'purple' }    // Color at 100%
  ],
}

rule.encode.enter.lineWidth.desc: Line width of the graphic element's stroke

rule.encode.enter.lineDash.desc: Type: number[] Line pattern mode of the graphic element's stroke

rule.encode.enter.lineDashOffset.desc: Offset of the graphic element's stroke line pattern mode

rule.encode.enter.lineCap.desc:
Line cap style of the graphic stroke, with the following optional options:

  • 'butt'
  • 'round'
  • 'square'

rule.encode.enter.lineJoin.desc:
Line join style of the graphic stroke, with the following optional options:

  • 'bevel'
  • 'miter'
  • 'round'

rule.encode.enter.miterLimit.desc: The limit value for the miter effect when the lineJoin type is miter

rule.encode.enter.strokeBoundsBuffer.desc: The boundsBuffer of the graphic stroke for controlling the buffer of the bounds

rule.encode.enter.shadowBlur.desc: The blur radius size of the graphic shadow

rule.encode.enter.shadowColor.desc:

    { offset: 0.8, color: 'green' },  // Color at 80%
    { offset: 1, color: 'purple' }    // Color at 100%
  ],
}

rule.encode.enter.shadowOffsetX.desc: The x offset of the graphic shadow

rule.encode.enter.shadowOffsetY.desc: The y offset of the graphic shadow

rule.encode.enter.dx.desc: The offset of the graphic in the x direction

rule.encode.enter.dy.desc: The offset of the graphic in the y direction

rule.encode.enter.dz.desc: The offset of the graphic in the z direction

rule.encode.enter.scrollX.desc: The scrolling offset of the graphic in the X direction

rule.encode.enter.scrollY.desc: The scrolling offset of the graphic in the y direction

rule.encode.enter.scaleX.desc: The scaling factor of the graphic in the x direction, default is no scaling, which is equivalent to a value of 1

rule.encode.enter.scaleY.desc: The scaling factor of the graphic in the y direction, default is no scaling, which is equivalent to a value of 1

rule.encode.enter.scaleZ.desc: The scaling factor of the graphic in the z direction, default is no scaling, which is equivalent to a value of 1

rule.encode.enter.angle.desc: The rotation angle of the graphic in the x-y plane, in 3d mode, corresponds to the rotation angle around the z-axis

rule.encode.enter.alpha.desc: The rotation angle around the y-axis in 3d mode

rule.encode.enter.beta.desc: The rotation angle around the x-axis in 3d mode

rule.encode.enter.background.desc:
The background color of the graphic, or the background image;

When setting the background color, supports using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, etc. to set solid colors, and also supports setting gradient color fills.

Gradient color configuration. Gradient colors can be configured on color-supporting properties such as fill and stroke in graphic styles. Currently supports three gradient configurations:

  • Linear gradient

    },
    {

      color: 'blue' // Color at 100%
    }
  ],
}
  • Radial gradient

  r0: 0,
  x1: 0.5,
  y1: 1,
  r1: 0.7,
  stops: [
    {
      offset: 0,
      color: 'rgba(255,255,255,0.5)' // Color at 0%
    },
    {
      offset: 1,
      color: '#6690F2' // Color at 100%
    }
  ]
}
  • Conical gradient
// Conical gradient, startAngle represents starting radian, endAngle represents ending radian, x and y are coordinates, and the value range is 0 - 1
{
  gradient: 'conical',
  x: 0.5,
  y: 0.5,

  endAngle: 6.283185307179586,
  stops: [
    { offset: 0, color: 'red' },      // Color at 0%
    { offset: 0.2, color: 'blue' },   // Color at 20%
    { offset: 0.4, color: 'orange' }, // Color at 40%
    { offset: 0.6, color: 'pink' },   // Color at 60%
    { offset: 0.8, color: 'green' },  // Color at 80%
    { offset: 1, color: 'purple' }    // Color at 100%
  ],
}

When setting images:

Image, supporting multiple formats:

  • string: Image URL
  • HTMLImageElement: The image tag corresponding to the image
  • HTMLCanvasElement: The canvas tag corresponding to the image

rule.encode.enter.backgroundMode.desc: The fill mode of the graphic background, depending on the specific graphic

rule.encode.enter.cursor.desc:
The mouse cursor style of the graphic, similar to DOM styles:

  • 'zoom-in'
  • 'zoom-out'

rule.encode.update.background.desc:
The background color of the graphic, or the background image;

When setting the background color, supports using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, etc. to set solid colors, and also supports setting gradient color fills.

Gradient color configuration. Gradient colors can be configured on color-supporting properties such as fill and stroke in graphic styles. Currently supports three gradient configurations:

  • Linear gradient
// Linear gradient, the first four parameters are x0, y0, x1, y1, ranging from 0 to 1, which is equivalent to the percentage within the bounding box of the graphic
{
  gradient: 'linear',
  x0: 0,
  y0: 0,
  x1: 0,
  y1: 1,
  stops: [
    {
      offset: 0,
      color: 'red' // Color at 0%
    },
    {
      offset: 1,
      color: 'blue' // Color at 100%
    }
  ],
}
  • Radial gradient
// Radial gradient, the first five parameters are x0, y0, r0, x1, y1, r1, where r0 and r1 represent radius, values are the same as linear gradient
{
  gradient: 'radial',
  x0: 0.5,
  y0: 0,
  r0: 0,
  x1: 0.5,
  y1: 1,
  r1: 0.7,
  stops: [
    {
      offset: 0,
      color: 'rgba(255,255,255,0.5)' // Color at 0%
    },
    {
      offset: 1,
      color: '#6690F2' // Color at 100%
    }
  ]
}
  • Conical gradient
// Conical gradient, startAngle represents starting radian, endAngle represents ending radian, x and y are coordinates, and the value range is 0 - 1
{
  gradient: 'conical',
  x: 0.5,
  y: 0.5,

    { offset: 0, color: 'red' },      // Color at 0%

    { offset: 1, color: 'purple' }    // Color at 100%
  ],
}

Image, supporting multiple formats:

  • string: Image URL
  • HTMLImageElement: The image tag corresponding to the image
